User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the WeatherWise Dashboard application.

email.description: The email address of the user.

displayName.description: The display name of the user.

photoURL.description: URL of the user's profile picture.

favoriteCities.description: An array of favorite city objects.

FavoriteCity.title: FavoriteCity
FavoriteCity.description: Represents a city that a user has marked as a favorite.

id.description: Unique identifier for the FavoriteCity entity from the weather API.

WeatherCache.title: WeatherCache
WeatherCache.description: Represents cached weather data to reduce API calls.

cityId.description: Identifier for the city (likely from the weather API).

weatherData.description: JSON string containing the cached weather data.

lastUpdated.description: Timestamp of the last time the cache was updated.

definition.description: Stores user profile information including their favorite cities. Uses path-based ownership; only the user can access their own document.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier of the user, matching their Firebase Auth UID.

definition.description: Stores cached weather data for each city, updated every 60 seconds. The 'cityId' serves as the document ID. Security rules should limit writes to a trusted server and allow public read access. This structure is optimized for fast retrieval of cached weather data.

params.name: cityId
params.description: The unique identifier of the city for which weather data is cached.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed for the WeatherWise Dashboard. The primary change is storing `favoriteCities` as an array of objects directly within the `User` document in the `/users/{userId}` collection. This simplifies the data model by eliminating the need for a subcollection. This design is efficient for reads, as a single document read fetches all of a user's profile and favorite cities. It's well-suited for scenarios where the number of favorites per user is not excessively large. The rest of the structure remains the same, with `weather_cache` for public data caching.
